tasker.lib¶

The TaskLib class provides the methods for managing tasks.

JUNK¶

The following methods are available to plugins through the cli property (for NewCommand objects) or the self.master property (for MinionCmd objects attached to SubCommand plugins).

TaskCmd.parse_task(text)¶

Returns a tuple of the following values:

  1. complete (boolean)
  2. priority (single character)
  3. start (datetime.datetime object)
  4. end (datetime.datetime object or None)
  5. task (string)
  6. contexts (tuple of contexts - words beginning with @)
  7. projects (tuple of projects - words beginning with +)
  8. extensions (dictionary of extension: value pairs)

parse_task() is a general utility function. The first five of these can be fused into a single line of text using graft().

TaskCmd.graft(c, p, s, e, t)¶

Returns a single text representing the task

The parameters match the first five components returned by parse_task().

TaskCmd.get_tasks(file_path)¶

Returns a dictionary of (line number, task text) pairs

Return type:dict
Parameters:path – path to the file to read
Returns:dictionary of line number, text pairs

Note

The first line is assigned the key 1 instead of 0

TaskCmd.write_tasks(task_dict, file_path)¶

Writes the working task_dictionary to the appropriate file

Parameters:task_dict (dict) – Dictionary of line-number: task pairs
Returns:results pair
TaskCmd.run_hooks(func_name, c, p, s, e, t, o, j, x)¶

Scans plugins for hooked features. Returns c, p, s, e, t.

This can allow for a plugin to write a listener method that adds something to the command queue or even alter the text of the todo.

Note

The task text is not re-parsed, so this could lead to confusion in the context and projects list and the extensions.

TaskCmd.add_task(text)¶

Appends a task directly to the file.

TaskCmd.add_done(text)¶

Adds a completed task to the list, allowing Tasker to serve as a log of actions.

This method calls TaskCmd.run_hooks() twice: once on creating the task and the second on completing the task.

TaskCmd.complete_task(tasknum, comment):

This is the method that do_do() calls.
